search_results.lyrics:
Night Shift Lyrics[Verse 1]
The first time I tasted somebody else's spit, I had a coughing fit
I mistakenly called them by your name
I was let down, it wasn't the same
I'm doing fine, trying to derail my one-track mind
Regaining my self-worth in record time
But I can't help but think of your other in the bed that was mine
Am I a masochist, resisting urges to punch you in the teeth?
Call you a bitch and leave?
Why did I come here? To sit and watch you stare at your feet?
What was the plan? Absolve your guilt and shake hands?
[Chorus]
I feel no need to forgive, but I might as well
But let me kiss your lips, so I know how it felt
Pay for my coffee and leave before the sun goes down
Walk for hours in the dark, feeling all hell

[Verse 2]
Don't hold your breath, forget you ever saw me at my best
You don't deserve what you don't respect
Don't deserve what you say you love and then neglect
Now bite your tongue, it's too dangerous to fall so young
Take back what you said
Can't lose what you never had

[Chorus]
I feel no need to forgive, but I might as well
But let me kiss your lips, so I know how it felt
Pay for my coffee and leave before the sun goes down
Walk for hours in the dark, feeling all hell

[Refrain]
You got a 9-to-5, so I'll take the night shift
And I'll never see you again, if I can help it
In five years, I hope the songs feel like covers
Dedicated to new lovers

And I'll never see you again, if I can help it

description.plain: The lead single off Lucy Dacus' sophomore album, Historian. The six-and-a-half minute track is about the aftermath of a break up, where she tries to move on and re-structure her life to avoid her ex-lover.

song.embed_content: Read “Night Shift” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: Night Shift

body.plain: The lead single off Lucy Dacus' sophomore album, Historian. The six-and-a-half minute track is about the aftermath of a break up, where she tries to move on and re-structure her life to avoid her ex-lover.

annotations:
Pay for my coffee and leave before the sun goes down
 Walk for hours in the dark, feeling all hell

After her and her ex have met up, she pays for her own coffee and removes herself from the situation, making sure she is gone before it is dark, but then after being cordial with her ex, feels horrible about seeing them and mulls over the experiences while walking.

This motif of night frames the song – Lucy takes the “night shift” and adjusts her life after the breakup, putting herself in a completely different time of day and mode in order to move on from the life that she previously led with her ex.

I feel no need to forgive, but I might as well
 But let me kiss your lips, so I know how it felt
Despite knowing what they did was unforgivable, some part of her feels wistful, dreaming of one last kiss to seal off their relationship
I was let down, it wasn’t the same
Lucy felt as though this kiss with somebody new was wrong, that her ex’s kisses weren’t the same. Leaving her with dissatisfaction over her efforts to move past the failed relationship.

Why did I come here? To sit and watch you stare at your feet?
 What was the plan? Absolve your guilt and shake hands?

These lines indicate Lucy and her ex-lover have met up together, most likely to talk about their relationship and the decision that lead to the breakup.
She watches her ex-lovers body language, and begins to regret meeting because of his guilt-tripping apology. Being only left with anger, she begins asking rhetorical questions, to what the point of meeting was, other than to make her feel guilty and letting Lucy’s ex-lover off scott-free, relieving him of his mistakes and moving on, something Lucy isn’t exactly ready for. We know it’s practical confirmed in the opening lines, by her calling someone else her ex’s name accidentally during a kiss.

This is further backs up her later lines of ‘needing to forgive’, so we can assume Lucy was not the wrong doer in this situation.

In five years, I hope the songs feel like covers
 Dedicated to new lovers

Here, the singer expresses hope that, by the time 5 years pass, she’ll have gotten over the relationship she is currently mourning. Essentially, she wants the songs that she and her ex-partner wrote for each other to take on new subjects in new lovers, similarly to if someone else were covering them and singing to their own partner.

Regaining my self-worth in record time
 But I can’t help but think of your other in the bed that was mine
Lucy is starting to regain her sense of self and worthiness but she also can’t stop thinking about her ex’s new partner in the bed that they used to sleep in together.
I feel no need to forgive, but I might as well

This line shows Dacus' maturity, as she chooses to forgive this person despite the hurt they have caused her. However, it could also show that her forgiveness isn’t genuine. She is simply tired of the conflict she has with this person, and, if proclaiming her forgiveness for them is the only way to end it, then that’s what she’ll do.

Am I a masochist, resisting urges to punch you in the teeth?
 Call you a bitch and leave?

A masochist is (in general use) a person who enjoys an activity that appears to be painful or tedious, I believe here she’s saying that she seems masochistic by resisting punching her lover in the teeth from all the pain and anger that was caused.
But let me kiss your lips

This suggests the “two-sided” feelings of the situation, that despite knowing she deserves better (suggested below) and that she was indeed mistreated, she still in a way long for the person’s warmth and intimacy.

You got a 9-to-5, so I’ll take the night shift
 And I’ll never see you again, if I can help it
She will do everything in her power, even adjusting her work schedule, to make sure she never has to see her ex lover again.

search_results.title: Hot & Heavy
search_results.lyrics:
Hot & Heavy Lyrics[Chorus]
Being back here makes me hot in the face
Hot blood in my pulsing veins
Heavy memories weighing on my brain
Hot and heavy in the basement of your parents' place
You used to be so sweet
Now you're a firecracker on a crowded street
Couldn't look away even if I wanted
Try to walk away but I come back to the start

[Verse]
Led me to the floor even though I'm not a dancer
Asked me all the questions that your parents wouldn't answer
How could I deny a diamond in the rough?
You let me in your world until you had enough
You knew that I wanted you to bend the rules
How did I believe I had a hold on you?
You were always stronger than people suspected
Underestimated and overprotected
When I went away, it was the only option
Couldn't trust myself to proceed with caution
The most that I could give to you was nothing at all
The best that I could offer was to miss your calls
[Chorus]
Being back here makes me hot in the face
Hot blood in my pulsing veins
Heavy memories weighing on my brain
Hot and heavy in the basement of your parents' place
You used to be so sweet
Now you're a firecracker on a crowded street
Couldn't look away even if I wanted
Try to walk away but I come back to the start

[Bridge]
And it happens over and over and over and over again
Over and over and over and over again
I wish I was over it, over it, over it, over it

[Outro]
A hidden gem, my own goldmine
You had the wide and wild eyes
You were a secret to yourself
You couldn't keep from anyone else
Now you're the biggest, brightest flame
You are a fire that can't be tamed
You're better than ever, but I knew you when
It's bittersweet to see you againYou might also like2Embed

description.plain:
In lead single from Home Video, Lucy Dacus uses a double entendre for “Hot & Heavy”. Whilst referring to the sexually charged “hot and heavy” idiom, it also links back to a red face (hot blood) and strong memories of the past (heavy memories).

As with the bulk of Home Video, “Hot & Heavy” is a heavily nostalgic track, reflecting on past friendships and romantic relationships. She explained to Pitchfork:

I thought I was writing this song about a friend of mine who used to be super reserved and is now very lively. We used to be close, but the more friends she made, the less we saw each other. Then I felt like I was writing about myself from the perspective of someone I had dated—like watching myself go through the process of learning about the world and being less closed off. Then I realized I was both characters.

song.embed_content: Read “Hot & Heavy” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: Hot & Heavy

body.plain:
In lead single from Home Video, Lucy Dacus uses a double entendre for “Hot & Heavy”. Whilst referring to the sexually charged “hot and heavy” idiom, it also links back to a red face (hot blood) and strong memories of the past (heavy memories).

As with the bulk of Home Video, “Hot & Heavy” is a heavily nostalgic track, reflecting on past friendships and romantic relationships. She explained to Pitchfork:

I thought I was writing this song about a friend of mine who used to be super reserved and is now very lively. We used to be close, but the more friends she made, the less we saw each other. Then I felt like I was writing about myself from the perspective of someone I had dated—like watching myself go through the process of learning about the world and being less closed off. Then I realized I was both characters.

annotations:
You’re better than ever, but I knew you when
 It’s bittersweet to see you again
Dacus is proud of who her old friend has become, but finds it bittersweet because their relationship was based on personalities that aren’t there anymore. They aren’t the person she misses.

You were always stronger than people suspected
 Underestimated and overprotected

Following the theme of someone “sweet” turned “firecracker,” saying this person was underestimated might mean that no one saw the potential of who they could be until they changed. It could also mean their development was “explosive” and sudden, and caught people off guard.
You let me in your world until you had enough
This line implies the subject of the song grew into someone that wasn’t as interested in Dacus’s company anymore.

You were a secret to yourself
 You couldn’t keep from anyone else

This lyric conjures the image of a childhood friend (or self in some interpretations) who has such a strong and precocious personality that the people around them see who they are before they are old enough to understand themselves.

Now you’re the biggest, brightest flame
 You are a fire that can’t be tamed

This can be a call back to the “Firecracker on a Crowded Street” line. This person is so explosive with their personality, it’s become so hard to recognize them as the same person as they were as a child.

You used to be so sweet
 Now you’re a firecracker on a crowded street

This carries the sentiment of a shy, innocent kid–but now coming back and seeing someone grown into their full person, they’re so loud so much more explosive than before. It could be taken as either a negative or positive thing.

search_results.title: Kissing Lessons

Kissing Lessons Lyrics[Verse 1]
Rachel was a year older
When I was in the second grade
I thought she might know everything
I took her word like a golden ring
I asked her how to win my man

[Verse 2]

I couldn't decide if she was Cole or Justin

We'd take turns being seduced
Imagining the day it would come into use
Imagining thе day we'd start breaking hearts
And taking namеs

[Bridge]
She wanted a three-story house
I wanted to live by a body of water
With my children and their father
Children and their father
Three sons and a beautiful daughter (Oh)

[Instrumental Break]

[Outro]
Rachel's family moved out of town
I don't remember when we stopped hanging out
But I still wear a letter R charm on my bracelet
And wonder if she thinks of me as her first kissYou might also like2Embed

description.plain:
Indie-pop singer Lucy Dacus delivers a tongue-in-cheek tune about getting advice from true friends with “Kissing Lessons”. The song’s promotion first began in late January 2022, as flyers with the phone number (804) 409-4451 offered a minute-and-a-half snippet of the song when called up. The song, together with its official music video, was released on February 2, 2022.

In her newsletter, Lucy stated that “Kissing Lessons” was originally written back in 2017, and then included in a test tracklist for her 2021 album Home Video before it was eventually discarded.

The song was also released in physical format (together with the other standalone single “Thumbs Again”), recorded on 7" vinyl discs available in baby blue and black limited editions.

body.plain:
Indie-pop singer Lucy Dacus delivers a tongue-in-cheek tune about getting advice from true friends with “Kissing Lessons”. The song’s promotion first began in late January 2022, as flyers with the phone number (804) 409-4451 offered a minute-and-a-half snippet of the song when called up. The song, together with its official music video, was released on February 2, 2022.

In her newsletter, Lucy stated that “Kissing Lessons” was originally written back in 2017, and then included in a test tracklist for her 2021 album Home Video before it was eventually discarded.

The song was also released in physical format (together with the other standalone single “Thumbs Again”), recorded on 7" vinyl discs available in baby blue and black limited editions.

annotations: I wanted to live by a body of water

The desire to raise children by water parallels Lucy’s friend’s desire in “Christine”:

She always wanted to raise a baby by the lake

In both cases, the implication is that the characters feel heteronormative pressure to settle into domestic roles. In contrast, in “Triple Dog Dare,” Lucy crafts a longing narrative where she and her friend, possibly the Rachel of this song, were able to break away from society and live on water rather than beside it:

I want to run away and live on your family’s boat

Water typically represents emotion and in Lucy’s discography, living closer to water could correspond to a greater degree of emotional fulfilment.
And taking names

children are taught from a young age the romanticised aspects of heterosexual marriage- including taking a husband’s name- what with it being so showcased in media and society. although rachel and lucy are being somewhat romantic with each other, these intentions are overridden by the traditional and heteronormative roles surrounding women and family.
But I still wear a letter R charm on my bracelet
the charm in question :
I took her word like a golden ring
While this simile indicates Dacus was “married” to her word, it’s also an interesting reference to the tension queer people feel with the idea of getting married

I couldn’t decide if she was Cole or Justin
 I think I called her baby or darling most the time
The “man” that Lucy sought out to win at the beginning is so irrelevant that she doesn’t even remember which one she had a crush on, opting instead to use neutral pet names for Rachel.
And wonder if she thinks of me as her first kiss

In a livestreamed interview with the music video’s director Mara Palena, Dacus said about this lyric,

I think that’s a common queer experience. If you kiss people in your youth, as you get older, maybe the world teaches you that that wasn’t legitimate. Because it wasn’t within a dating relationship or it wasn’t publicly known, there are lots of ways that you can de-legitimize yourself.

With my children and their father
 Children and their father

In a livestreamed interview/chat between Dacus and the music video’s director, Mara Palena, from February 3, 2022, Dacus said about these lyrics:
“Saying it twice, it feels a little like I’m trying to convince myself that that’s what I want.”

description.plain:
“I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore” is the first track and first single on Lucy Dacus’s debut album, No Burden, which was released on September 9, 2016.

The song is about the speaker’s desire to change her role in the group despite the fact that such a sharp pivot in identity is unusual and isn’t as explicit a process as she proposes.

She sorts through the different roles that she could switch to and outlines how she can assume that role. While the speaker despairs about how entrenched her identity seems to be, it also shows the absurdity of the distinct roles that people take on during young adulthood and their cliched markers.

body.plain:
“I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore” is the first track and first single on Lucy Dacus’s debut album, No Burden, which was released on September 9, 2016.

The song is about the speaker’s desire to change her role in the group despite the fact that such a sharp pivot in identity is unusual and isn’t as explicit a process as she proposes.

She sorts through the different roles that she could switch to and outlines how she can assume that role. While the speaker despairs about how entrenched her identity seems to be, it also shows the absurdity of the distinct roles that people take on during young adulthood and their cliched markers.

songs.full_title: I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore (Audiotree Live Version) by Lucy Dacus
songs.title: I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore (Audiotree Live Version)
songs.title_with_featured: I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore (Audiotree Live Version)

annotations: I don’t wanna be funny anymore

It’s a burden for her to be labelled as the funny one, because not only are her friends laughing at her jokes, they’re laughing at her. She both doesn’t want to be actively funny, as in the one making jokes, or funny as in the subject of the jokes.

I don’t want the joke to be on me
 Yeah, I’ll buy the clothes and I’ll be the best dressed
 Yeah, I’ll read the books and I’ll be the smartest
 I’ll play guitar and I’ll be the artist

The introspective nature of this song reveals Dacus’ inner frustration with being cast as a certain archetype, and being put into a box. She explores a range of different tropes, expressing her desire to reinvent herself and to be perceived as something other than just ‘funny’, as people are multifaceted and should not be expected to conform to the one personality type. She reveals in an interview with The Fader: “getting people to take you seriously is an uphill battle, but it is all worth it”.

I don’t wanna be funny anymore
 I got a too-short skirt, maybe I can be the cute one

In an interview for The Fader, Dacus reveals how stressful it is to be pegged as a certain type of person and having to constantly live up to the identity that people assign to you. Dacus’ inner frustrations with having to live up to being ‘the funny one’ stem from her childhood where she was always slightly envious of the other tropes, she often thought: ‘why can’t I be the cute one, the smart one, the mysterious one, the one that’s good at dodgeball?’. Although now she knows she doesn’t have to be put into a box, there is still the lingering resentment of having to constantly live up to being positive and vivacious, to avoid disappointing others
Try not to laugh
“try not to laugh” is a common phrase people use when they’re going to confess a change in their life. In this case Lucy’s change is not wanting to be funny

Lately, I’ve been feeling like the odd man out
 I hurt my friends saying things I don’t mean out loud

The speaker’s desire to change her role in the group is apparently caused by two things:

1) She feels like she’s being excluded. The class clown is usually an outsider position and the fact that you’re performing for everyone else can make you feel even more of an outsider. The laughter of the group may have also become at her rather than with her.

2) Her jokes haven’t been landing well lately as she has resorted to fake insults which were not received well.

Brando Lyrics[Verse 1]

To go with you to the movies
You knew you were uncool
But you thought you could fool me

For the elderly and me and you
Fred and Ginger, black and white

[Verse 2]

Is that you never knew me like you thought you did

Like you thought you did

Thinking I wouldn't understand the reference
You admit, you think we're fated
I'll be lucky if I'm your third wife

We've been breathing the same air for too long
If the snow wasn't coming down so hard
I would open the door and walk home

What could go wrong
If I hitch a ride with a guy in a pickup

Is that you never knew me like you thought you did

song.embed_content: Read “Brando” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: Brando

annotations: I didn’t know what you meant

This line is incredibly ironic – someone calls her cerebral, meaning intelligent & mentally focused, but she juxtaposes that by saying she didn’t know what it meant, disproving the speaker’s analysis of her.

You told me to skip school
 To go with you to the movies
 You knew you were uncool
 But you thought you could fool me
 They play oldies in the afternoon
 For the elderly and me and you

Lucy attended Maggie L. Walker Governor’s School in the heart of Richmond, Virginia. The school grounds were not too far from Carytown, a well-known neighborhood with a popular dining, shopping, and entertainment district. Located on the edge of Carytown is the Byrd Theatre, a second-run movie theater built in 1928 which is known for its consistent schedule of “oldies” or classic films such as the undermentioned It’s a Wonderful Life.

All I need for you to admit
 Is that you never knew me like you thought you did
 You never knew me like you thought you did
 Like you thought you did

This epitomises the kind of toxic and unbalanced friendship the song is about. The speaker wants so badly for the other person to admit that they didn’t know her like they thought they did, but this is one thing that will probably never happen given the fact that the main problem in their relationship was the subject’s superiority complex, wanting to ‘teach’ the speaker while never actually being interested in or satisfied with her as a person.

You admit, you think we’re fated
 I’ll be lucky if I’m your third wife
 That’s only something you would say in the car
 We’ve been breathing the same air for too long

Dacus juxtaposes their perspectives on the relationship here: he’s viewing it in terms of destiny and Old Hollywood romance, but she sees him as the type to get caught up in the moment and end up cycling through multiple “true loves”.
The line “We’ve been breathing the same air for too long” suggests the toxicity of the friendship, which turns nasty after spending too much time together; the imagery Dacus creates is as if one friend’s air is poisonous to the other after too much exposure. Additionally, it shows how the subject of the song does not really care for her and is sometimes cruel to her, believing themselves superior: “I’ll be lucky if I’m your third wife.”

But now I do, would it have killed you
 To call me pretty instead?

Dacus’ words here seem to echo the sentiments of her 2016 single “I Don’t Wanna Be Funny Anymore”, where she rejects the idea of being being pigeonholed into a certain role or identity by those around her.

I don’t wanna be funny anymore
I got a too-short skirt, maybe I can be the cute one

It also highlights how the subject of the song enjoys feeling superior and more intelligent compared to Dacus, where even when they are complimenting her they can’t just give her straightforward praise: “would it have killed you” suggests the frequency of these small reservations building up over time, irritating the speaker.
You called me cerebral
Someone who uses their brain rather than their heart.

You say, “Here’s lookin’ at you, kid”
 Thinking I wouldn’t understand the reference

“Here’s looking at you, kid” is a line from the romance movie Casablanca (1942). In the scene, the character Rick (Humphrey Bogart) is saying goodbye to Ilsa (Ingrid Bergman).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rEWaqUVac3M&ab_channel=Movieclips

I’m in a second-story window
 And you’re yelling at me, “Stella!”
 And I’m laughing ’cause you think you’re Brando
 But you’ll never come close

“Stella!” is a famous line from the 1951 film A Streetcar Named Desire. Marlon Brando’s character, Stanley Kowalski, is yelling for his wife Stella in a passionate plea for her to take him back.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kYA9hvcLekg&ab_channel=Movieclips

Fred and Ginger, black and white
 I watch you watch It’s a Wonderful Life

Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers were dance partners in a number of mostly black-and-white movies from the 1930s and 40s. It’s A Wonderful Life is a 1946 film starring James Stewart. Throughout the song, Dacus makes quite a few references to old movies that she and her friend saw at the cinema.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MANfbqtZN0&ab_channel=0918525115209185251152

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lxNXtjGY_Us&ab_channel=RobertScheribelRobertScheribel

search_results.full_title: It's Too Late by Lucy Dacus
search_results.title: It’s Too Late
search_results.lyrics:
It’s Too Late Lyrics[Verse 1]
Stayed in bed all morning just to pass the time
There's something wrong here, there can be no denying
One of us is changing
Or maybe we just stopped trying

[Chorus]
And it's too late, baby, now it's too late
Though we really did try to make it
Something inside has died
And I can't hide and I just can't fake it
No, no
[Verse 2]
It used to be so easy living here with you
You were light and breezy and I knew what to do
Now you look so unhappy and I feel like a fool

[Chorus]
And it's too late, baby, now it's too late
Though we really did try to make it
Something inside has died
And I can't hide and I just can't fake it
Oh, no

[Instrumental Break]

[Verse 3]
There'll be good times again for me and you
But we just can't stay together, don't you feel it, too?
Still, I'm glad for what we had and how I once loved you

[Chorus]
But it's too late, baby, now it's too late
Though we really did try to make it
Something inside has died
And I can't hide and I just can't fake it
Oh, no
You might also like[Outro]
It's too late, baby
It's too late now, darling
It's too lateEmbed

search_results.title: Christine
search_results.lyrics:
Christine Lyrics[Verse 1]
You're falling asleep
On my shoulder in the back of your boyfriend's car
We're coming home
From a sermon saying how bent on evil we are
I try to imagine what you're dreaming
You're muttering nonsense between steady breathing
I have to wake you up to get out
Your man waves from the end of the drive 'til I'm in the house

[Chorus]
He can be nice, sometimes
Other nights, you admit he's not what you had in mind
All in all, nobody's perfect
Therе may be better, but you don't feel worth it
That's whеre we disagree
[Verse 2]
You always wanted to raise a baby by the lake
Maybe they'll grow up and never make the same mistakes
Knowing you, they'd be the first kid to never hurt another
I see you look at him and wonder if he'll make you a mother

[Outro]
But if you get married, I'd object
Throw my shoe at the altar and lose your respect
I'd rather lose my dignity
Than lose you to somebody who won't make you happyYou might also like5Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Christine” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: Christine

annotations:
I’d rather lose my dignity
 Than lose you to somebody who won’t make you happy

This line shows how important the other person (“Christine”) is to her. The beginning of the song reflects Dacus’ strong religious upbringing: “we’re coming home from a sermon saying how bent and evil we are”.

She’d rather embarrass herself in front of her religious community (throwing her shoe at the altar) than let Christine marry someone who can’t give her happiness (like Dacus herself).
You always wanted to raise a baby by the lake
Possibly a reference to “Kissing Lessons” where Dacus says “I wanted to live by a body of water with my children and their father, children and their father”

We’re coming home
 From a sermon saying how bent on evil we are

As a young adult, Lucy attended church four nights per week, “different churches with friends.”

The phrase “bent on evil” appears several times in the Bible, generally refering to humantiy’s inclination to lean towards “evil”, dating back to the original sin.

Lucy told Apple Music:

[We were] coming home from a sermon that was about how humans are evil and children especially need to be guided or else they’ll fall into the hands of the devil.

But if you get married, I’d object
 Throw my shoe at the altar and lose your respect

Although it is not as common now, wedding officiants (particularly Christian ones) would often include a section in their speech asking if anyone objects to the marriage. In accordance with the Book of Common Prayer, the spiel reads as follows:

Should anyone present know of any reason that this couple should not be joined in holy matrimony, speak now or forever hold your peace.

In a tweet on June 27, 2021, Dacus explained that the lyric was inspired by the 2008 Bush shoeing incident, in which Iraqi journalist Muntadhar al-Zaidi
 famously threw his shoes at U.S. president George W. Bush in protest of the Iraq War.

https://twitter.com/lucydacus/status/1409160190310686728

search_results.title: Please Stay
search_results.lyrics:
Please Stay Lyrics[Verse 1]
Your clothes in the dryer
Your hair on the shower wall
Your toothbrush is too much
Your shoes empty in the hall
Your keys on the counter
Your dirty dish in the sink
Please don't make me see these things

[Verse 2]
The books on your shelf that you never read
The hunting knife you kept by your bed
The flowers you dried and tied up with twine
Suspended from the ceiling
[Pre-Chorus]
You tell me you love me like it'll be thе last time
Like you're playing out thе end of a storyline
I say I love you too because it's true
What else am I supposed to do?
Maybe bar the door when you move to leave

[Chorus]
I think you mean what you say
When you say you wanna die
I think you mean what you say
When you say you want to stay alive

[Bridge]
Quit your job
Cut your hair
Get a dog
Change your name
Change your mind
Change your ways
Give them time
Go back to school, go back to sleep
Tell the secret you can't keep
Begin, be done
Break a vow, make a new one
Call me if you need a friend or never talk to me again
You might also like[Outro]
But please stay
But please stay
But please stay
But please stay2Embed

description.plain: Please Stay is a song about feeling almost helpless around someone you love. Lucy expresses that she wants this person to know how much they matter, that they need to keep living. She feels somewhat of a responsibility to make sure this person knows that living is enough, and emphasizes that she would notice they’re gone.

song.embed_content: Read “Please Stay” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: Please Stay

body.plain: Please Stay is a song about feeling almost helpless around someone you love. Lucy expresses that she wants this person to know how much they matter, that they need to keep living. She feels somewhat of a responsibility to make sure this person knows that living is enough, and emphasizes that she would notice they’re gone.

annotations:
But please stay
 But please stay
 But please stay
 But please stay

A common feature of Dacus' writing is repetition of important or emotionally impactful lines.

For example, in the song Nonbeliever, the line
“Everybody else, everybody else looks like they’ve figured it out,” is repeated multiple times in the outro, as it encapsulates the message of the song.

In this case, repeating the line “But please stay” shows the desperation Dacus feels, as she is unsure what to say or do, highlighting a feeling of uncertainty that has been present throughout the song, (“I say I love you too, because it’s true // What else am I supposed to do?”)

It also emphasises that this simple request is all she is asking of this person, concluding the message of the song: she wants this person to stay alive, no matter what it takes to do so.

What else am I supposed to do?
 Maybe bar the door when you move to leave

This demonstrates Dacus' helplessness when it comes to stopping the person from committing suicide. The desperation behind physically barring the door suggests that Dacus will do anything to help this person, even if she doesn’t quite know how.

Your clothes in the dryer
 Your hair on the shower wall
 Your toothbrush is too much
 Your shoes empty in the hall
 Your keys on the counter
 Your dirty dish in the sink
 Please don’t make me see these things

Dacus is listing the day-to-day mundane things that remind her of the person she’s singing about. It slowly dawns on listeners that she’s imagining how painful everyday moments will be if that person leaves/kills themself. In the last line, she uses this as a reason for that person to stay. This also establishes a degree of intimacy and love for the song’s subject.

Quit your job
 Cut your hair
 Get a dog
 Change your name
 Change your mind
 Change your ways
 Give them time
 Go back to school, go back to sleep
 Tell the secret you can’t keep
 Begin, be done
 Break a vow, make a new one
 Call me if you need a friend or never talk to me again

Do anything with your life, ruin it, but don’t end it, just stay another day.

Dacus is encouraging her friend to make any sort of drastic changes that could improve their life—no matter how destructive they may be—as an alternative for ending their life

I think you mean what you say
 When you say you wanna die
 I think you mean what you say
 When you say you want to stay alive

Dacus said Please Stay was about being a “friend to someone who doesn’t think they should continue living and you are trying with everything at your disposal to tell them otherwise, everything feels like fair game. Do anything with your life, ruin it, but don’t end it, just stay another day—that kind of thing. I’ve had a lot of friends throughout my life that have contemplated or committed suicide, and I’ve been involved to varying degrees, as someone they can talk to or be physically around. The sense of clarity in situations like that is so profound, like the only thing that matters is that you’re here.”

via Pitchfork
https://pitchfork.com/features/song-by-song/lucy-dacus-interview-new-album-home-video/

The hunting knife you kept by your bed
 The flowers you dried and tied up with twine
 Suspended from the ceiling
The imagery of a knife by the bed and dead flowers hanging from the ceiling are both suggestive of methods of suicide.

search_results.title: VBS
search_results.lyrics:
VBS Lyrics[Verse 1]
In the summer of '07, I was sure I'd go to Heaven
But I was hedging my bets at VBS
A preacher in a T-shirt told me I could be a leader
Taught me how to build a fire and to spread The Word
In the evening, everybody went to worship and weep
Hands above our heads, reaching for God
Back in the cabin, snorting nutmeg in your bunk bed
You were waiting for a revelation of your own
Sedentary secrets like peach pits in your gut
Locked away like jam jars in the cellar of your heart
Waiting to be tasted and ultimately wasted
You were gonna win me over from the start

[Chorus]
Your poetry was so bad
It took a lot to not laugh
You say that I showed you the light
But all it did, in the end
Was make the dark feel darker than before

[Verse 2]
Your dad keeps his sleeves down through the summer for a reason
Your mother wears her makeup extra thick for a reason
When I tell you you were born and you are here for a reason
You are not convinced the reason is a good one

While you're going to sleep, your mind keeps you awake
And it makes your heart beat fast and loud
There's nothing you can do, but the only thing you've found:
Playing Slayer at full volume helps to drown it out

[Chorus]
Your poetry was so bad
It took a lot to not laugh
You say that I showed you the light
But all it did, in the end
Was make the dark feel darker than before
Dark feel darker than before
Dark feel darker than beforeYou might also like2Embed

description.plain: “VBS”, which stands for “vacation bible school", is the third single from Home Video. In the song, Dacus talks about her experiences attending vacation bible school, where she met her first boyfriend.

song.embed_content: Read “VBS” by Lucy Dacus on Genius
song.title: VBS

body.plain: “VBS”, which stands for “vacation bible school", is the third single from Home Video. In the song, Dacus talks about her experiences attending vacation bible school, where she met her first boyfriend.

annotations: A preacher in a T-shirt told me I could be a leader

Often Christian youth ministers will appear casual, especially at Vacation Bible Schools, to seem more approachable.

Additionally, they manipulate those they preach to by excessively complimenting those they wish to become believers.
Taught me how to build a fire and to spread The Word

I think Lucy used a clever double meaning with the line “taught me how to build a fire.” On the one hand, Lucy could be drawing from images of summer camp, like singing around a campfire and learning outdoorsy life skills, making the fire in the line literal. On the other hand, the song’s criticism of vbs camps and the messages they teach to young kids could imply the use of the phrase as a metaphor for evangelism, playing off the cliche “light a spark/start a movement.“ This also relates back to the previous line, where Lucy’s pastor tells her that she could be a leader.
Playing Slayer at full volume helps to drown it out

Slayer was an American thrash/speed metal band who played fast and heavy hard rock featuring darkly violent lyrics. Ironically, the only thing that seems to calm the character’s restlessness and anxiety is this loud and aggressive music. The fact that he is obsessed with a band that has been accused of promoting Satanism is, of course, one more reason that the protagonist would feel a need to save his soul.

In the evening, everybody went to worship and weep
 Hands above our heads, reaching for God

If you’ve ever been to bible camp or a youth retreat, you may have experienced what Dacus describes here. “Cry Night” is the name colloquially used for camp programming designed to provoke heightened emotional responses in campers. Often at the very end of the experience, Cry Night can include a wide altar call, emotional singalongs, group reflection, and group sharing of spiritual hardship and triumph. As one youth minister describes her experience:

The first time I cried at a retreat, I was a freshman in high school. At the end of the weekend, completely exhausted and sleep-deprived, the band led us in Michael W. Smith’s “Friends Are Friends Forever.” As we belted out this song, we threw our arms around one another’s shoulders and swayed as tears poured down our faces. We were high on God, each other and this mountaintop experience.

The practice was also prominently featured in the 2006 documentary Jesus Camp. Critics have called out Cry Nights like that depicted in Jesus Camp as emotionally manipulative.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cNMRDmf3000&ab_channel=Movieclips

In the summer of ’07, I was sure I’d go to Heaven
 But I was hedging my bets at VBS

From Dacus' interview with Pitchfork:

I went to church four out of seven nights a week—different churches with friends. It was the social avenue. The “hedging my bets” part of the song is about how you never know for sure if you’re doing the right thing. Faith without worship, I thought at the time, was empty. How would God know that you are devoted without expressing it?

You say that I showed you the light
 But all it did, in the end
 Was make the dark feel darker than before

Some strands of Christianity draw criticism for their fear-based teaching—by focusing their worship on the consequences of sin and the torments of hell, they compel people to follow the Christian God not out of love but out of fear. Such critiques often focus on the impact fear-based teaching has on children, who will evangelize to friends and family out of a genuine fear that their loved ones will go to hell. Dacus seems to have experienced something similar growing up: as Pitchfork reports, “she was devoutly Christian with a bit of a self-admitted savior complex.”

Thus, even though her boyfriend feels that he’s seen the light because of her, she suggests that what she’s teaching him as a leader at VBS ultimately might just be scaring him into believing or making him feel more hopeless.

When I tell you you were born and you are here for a reason
 You are not convinced the reason is a good one

She tries to convince him that God put him on Earth for a reason, but he is not convinced that it is worth it. Since these lines come directly after the allusion to his parents' physical abuse, the lyrics suggest that his disillusionment with religion stems from his troubled home life.

Your dad keeps his sleeves down through the summer for a reason
 Your mother wears her makeup extra thick for a reason
The suggestion here is that his parents have a physically violent relationship and have to hide their scratches and bruises.

Sedentary secrets like peach pits in your gut
 Locked away like jam jars in the cellar of your heart

In Partner In Crime, Dacus sings about another formative relationship with an unhealthy lean and uses the symbolism of another fruit, cherries:

Eating cherries on the bridge, feet dangling
Throwing the pits and stems into the racing current below

Back in the cabin, snorting nutmeg in your bunk bed
 You were waiting for a revelation of your own

Nutmeg contains an compound called myristicin which has hallucinogenic properties. This can be ingested, snorted or smoked, but this isn’t recommended. The dose required (25 grams), aside from being quite unpleasant to take in those quantities, will have an effect lasting up to 72 hours, can make people feel ill and can cause significant, even fatal heart problems. https://www.wsbtv.com/news/teens-snorting-nutmeg-for-cheap-high_nfbjy/241691904/
